Further safeguards will be included in the bill by the government amendments which will insert a maximum limit of four hours as a reasonable time for which a suspect can be detained for the conduct of the procedure. As in part 1C, certain time is excluded in calculating the expiry of the four-hour limit. Such time includes waiting for the suspect's interview friend, lawyer or doctor to arrive or allowing the suspect to communicate with a friend, relative, lawyer or interpreter.

As well as introducing time limits, the new part repeats those safeguards provided to arrest of persons under part 1C which are applicable to the conduct of forensic procedures. These include the right of certain suspects to interview friends; the right of all suspects to contact a lawyer and to communicate with that lawyer in private wherever possible; the right to an interpreter where necessary; and tape recording of requests for consent and the conduct of procedures.

However, in my view, a most potent safeguard in the present bill is provided by the legislative barrier to admissibility of evidence which is obtained from forensic procedures which are carried out in breach of the legislation. If there is any breach, the prosecution must justify to the court that there are good reasons why the statutory scheme was not followed. In such a case, the probative value of the evidence will not, by itself, justify its admission. The bill indicates a number of matters which the court must take into account in considering whether to admit such evidence, including the gravity of the contravention and whether it was intentional or reckless. Evidence is also inadmissible by the prosecution, with no discretion on the part of the court, where material was not destroyed in the circumstances required by the legislation. There are comprehensive requirements for the destruction of forensic material and inadmissibility of evidence derived from it, where proceedings have not been commenced within a certain period or where they have been finally determined.

I should like to mention three further points which have caused some concern. The first is the provision which permits the fact of a person's refusal to comply with any reasonable direction for the carrying out of a forensic procedure on a person, given by an authorised person, to be admissible in any proceedings against the person in a court, provided he or she has first been warned of that possibility. That is, admissibility is not limited to proceedings for non-compliance with a court order, or obstructing an officer in the course of his or her duty, but is admissible in the proceedings for the offence for which the forensic procedure was required. Accordingly, it is open to the jury to draw an inference from the person's refusal to permit the taking of the sample, which could involve the conclusion that the person had reason to fear the result of the procedure. One could, no doubt, imagine innocent reasons for resisting certain procedures, and these could be cogently put to the jury by the defence, with supporting evidence.

However, I believe that, where serious offences carrying heavy penalties are involved, without some serious consequence rendering non-compliance of doubtful value, a mere non-compliance offence with the usual low penalty would be an ineffective deterrent. It could defeat the value of the coercive provisions in the legislation—the penalty a price willingly paid by a guilty suspect to avoid the availability of damning evidence of the more serious offence and there would be little point in proceeding with this legislation.

The second matter is the retention and use of forensic material. There are two aspects to this. The bill provides for a database to be set up and maintained for statistical purposes. That database must be designed in such a way that the information contained in it cannot be used to identify any individual on whom a forensic procedure was carried out. Such a database will be used for a purely scientific purpose to develop norms against which the degree of probability that any particular forensic material came from a particular person can be assessed.

The second aspect is the requirement that information about a person obtained from a forensic sample taken under the bill may not be recorded or retained in a personal records system if that sample is required by the bill to be destroyed. However, nothing in this bill affects the taking, retention, or use of a forensic sample, or of information from that sample, where that is authorised by another law of the Commonwealth or of a state or territory. It is not intended to repeal any other Commonwealth provisions that might exist, although these can if necessary be revised in due course, nor is it intended to create any inconsistency with existing state-territory provisions. It is expected that these will be revised as state-territory legislation is developed to build up a national uniform scheme.

Finally, I will briefly address criticisms that forensic evidence in recent years has fallen into disrepute, that it is not infallible, and that juries, blinded with science, may give disproportionate weight to evidence of dubious validity. However, as I noted previously, no-one suggests that its use should be abandoned and almost everyone acknowledges its value when properly used.

All I wish to say on that issue is that the present bill is concerned only with the procedural aspects of collecting and using forensic material. The procedures which are currently available are subject to varying, often minimal, safeguards. This bill aims to balance the need of law enforcement to have access to an investigative resource, which is constantly being developed and refined, as against the right of the individual to live free of arbitrary intrusion by the state, and free of arbitrary interference with his or her physical integrity and dignity.

The products of the procedures provided by the bill, like the products of any other investigative technique, are weighed and evaluated as they pass through each of the filters provided by our criminal justice system: first by the investigators themselves, then by the prosecutors and their experts, then by the defence and its experts, and finally by the jury. Like all other evidence, it is subjected to the rigours of the adversary procedure. Experts are examined and cross-examined, the judge directs the jury on the applicable law and the standard of proof which must be satisfied, and the jury considers its verdict, taking into account all other evidence admitted as relevant in the proceedings.

If the view that this bill is bad and should be rejected because forensic evidence is less than 100 per cent reliable were applied to all evidence, the criminal courts would be cleared and no-one would ever be convicted. The standard of proof that is applied by the jury in a criminal trial is `beyond reasonable doubt'. That is a high test. In my opinion we must do the best we can with the means currently available to us. We must neither sacrifice civil liberties for expediency, nor reject available investigative techniques because they fall short of the standard of perfection.

The only financial implications arising from the bill involve minor costs associated with training which will be absorbed in the normal budgets of relevant agencies. Other aspects of the bill are described in the explanatory memorandum and a detailed description of the government amendments are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum which I now present. I commend the bill and the government amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour in my remarks to outline some concerns about the way in which the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995 is being handled by the government and our response to those procedures and then offer some comments of a preliminary nature in relation to the bill itself. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) enunciated in his second reading speech, this bill has a been a long time coming. I note that these matters were first raised in 1975, very early in the Law Reform Commission's days, in the Australian Law Reform Commission report No. 2, and reaffirmed in greater detail, after thorough examination of the issues, in the fifth interim report of the Review of the Commonwealth Criminal Law in 1991. So these matters were first raised in 1975, were the subject of further elaboration in 1991, and have been the subject of a number of other reviews and comments.

PARA.TAB: One wonders why, in the context of the government having taken positions which were beyond the recommendations of many of its expert bodies that have given advice in developing this bill, we are being pressed to debate this bill in this chamber today when it is well known that an inquiry has been instituted by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. That committee was due to report yesterday but because of the difficulty in completing its work it has obtained an extension of time to undertake its deliberations and it is now to report by 26 October, next Thursday.

The situation is that the Senate, through its committee, has been able to have a detailed examination of the bill. It has been able to hear from ministers, from the Law Council, presumably from other groups interested in privacy such as the councils of civil liberties, and from other interested bodies. However, this chamber, the House of Representatives, as is usual in relation to legislation involving the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), has not been able through its committees to undertake a similar review for the purposes of considering the bill.

We are asked, in the House of Representatives, to debate the bill, to allow it to have a second reading, and to consider government amendments before we have had the benefit of the Senate committee's observations on this bill. Why is that the case? Why the haste? Why is the House of Representatives to be excluded from this process, particularly when the bill has been in genesis since 1975? Is it suddenly so urgent that a week is going to matter? Just to say that out aloud demonstrates the patent nonsense involved in the timetable that the government has set.

We did endeavour the other day to give the government an opportunity to put this matter off and not refer it to this committee and to have the second reading postponed until the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee has reported to the Senate on the bill. We were not successful in that. The government used its numbers, notwithstanding what I believe would be the many doubts in the minds of some of its members about the efficacy of this particular legislation.
We want to give government members another opportunity to reconsider this matter and I will be moving:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the debate on the second reading of this Bill be adjourned, and the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the first sitting following 26 October 1995".

We will ask that that vote be taken at the conclusion of the speeches from those members who are listed here today to participate in this debate. That will give others, who may, as a result of the Senate committee deliberations, want to participate on the basis of that available information, an opportunity to do so, and it will enable the more important consideration in detail stage to be deferred until we have the Senate committee report.

PARA.TAB: I will ask that after the vote is taken in this place, which I gather has to be on the voices, the matter be referred back to the House of Representatives to enable a division to be taken. In that way we can see whether or not those members of the government who are interested in the civil liberty issues have something further to add. It is unlikely that they will want to disagree with the government but at least people should be given the opportunity to turn their minds to these issues. We will see whether they are bona fide when they speak to us in hushed tones about their concerns and whether they want to see a full debate.

I conclude in relation to the handling of this issue by saying that we are exceedingly disappointed at the way in which the Minister for Justice has dealt with this issue. I am disappointed additionally that the parliamentary secretary has left the chamber. The minister had the good sense, when the shadow Attorney wrote to him inviting him to postpone the consideration of this matter until after the Senate committee deliberations, to concur that that was an appropriate course to follow. But, when the committee was not able to complete its deliberations within the time frame initially anticipated to be met, the Minister for Justice came to a different view and wanted this timetable pressed. He gave us written advice that he would defer it in order that the principled course would be followed but, when the reporting date went back, he did not continue that approach.

I would just note, when we look at the list of speakers who are to contribute to this debate, that, notwithstanding our knowledge of the very considerable interest in this matter amongst government members, none have been prepared to come into the chamber and speak in the second reading debate in support of the government's bill. It is particularly interesting that, when we have a committee on legal and constitutional affairs which includes many highly qualified members of the legal profession who take an interest in these matters, some of them on the government benches, not one of them has seen fit to add their name to the list and to contribute to this debate. As I proceed to speak about the bill itself, it will become apparent why those who have a genuine interest might be silent at this time.

I take members firstly through the background of the legislation that is before us. At common law, there is no power to compel a suspect to provide body samples. The right of every person to maintain their bodily integrity is a long stated principle of law, and was recently reaffirmed in the High Court in 1992 in Marion's case. The current state and territory laws relating to forensic procedures are vague and the safeguards are varied.

As I mentioned earlier, quite a number of inquiries have been constituted to look at the questions of police powers and procedures in relation to forensic samples being taken. These include the Australian Law Reform Commission report on criminal investigation in 1975; a report on body samples and examinations in 1989 by the Victorian Consultative Committee on Police Powers of Investigation, known as the Coldrey committee; the fifth interim report in 1991 of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, known as the Gibbs committee; and the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission's report of 1994. In a number of significant respects, this bill gives police greater powers than those recommended by these various reports. In other words, the government in this proposed bill is going beyond the recommendations of the experts who have deliberated long and hard on this matter.

The bill before the parliament is based upon the model provisions developed by the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I do not know whether we have an acronym for that, but it is a very interesting long title. The final form of the bill was determined by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, presumably after the officers had presented them with appropriate recommendations.

The bill's provisions deal with what are termed intimate forensic procedures—and we heard a good deal of that being outlined in the second reading speech of the parliamentary secretary—and, separately, with non-intimate forensic procedures. The intimate forensic procedures include the taking of blood, the taking of dental impressions and procedures involving the genital areas and, in the case of women, their breasts. Non-intimate procedures include the taking of fingerprints, the taking of non-pubic hair and other less intrusive procedures not involving the genital areas. The scheme of the bill is to impose greater controls over the taking of intimate forensic procedures.

The bill draws distinctions between adults in custody; adults not in custody; incapable persons; and children under 18, whether or not they are in custody. In proposed section 23W there are various requirements for taking forensic procedures. I will not elaborate on the detailed outline given by the parliamentary secretary, save to say that the procedures are different, depending upon whether or not a person is in custody, not in custody, incapable or a child under 18 years of age.

The bill stipulates the persons who may carry out a particular forensic procedure. Depending upon the procedures, those persons may be a medical practitioner, a nurse, a dentist, a dental technician or an appropriately qualified person. In addition, in respect of most forensic procedures, the bill entitles the suspect to request the presence of a medical practitioner or dentist of the suspect's choice.

The reaction to the bill has ranged between full support; support as to the concept, but concern over the substance of the bill in particular areas; and outright opposition. Those expressing a reaction in the last category have claimed that the bill is an inappropriate invasion of the civil liberties of individuals and has potentially discriminatory effects upon Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and children.

In the view of the opposition the bill is not, in its broad terms, objectionable. As I noted, inquiries have recommended the enactment of a number of comprehensive laws dealing with police powers and forensic samples. However, any legislative scheme must appropriately balance the need to authorise the gathering of probative evidence against unnecessary intrusion on individual rights. Many claim that the balance has not been appropriately struck in this legislation. I will take the Committee through a number of the concerns that we have had expressed to us in relation to this legislation.

Firstly, in authorising the taking of forensic procedures before a person has been arrested, the bill gives police powers contrary to the recommendations of the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee. The explanatory memorandum and now the second reading speech seem to justify this provision on the basis that the criterion for authorising the taking of a sample requires the police to believe that there are grounds to arrest the person. In fact, the criterion for authorisation is that the constable suspects on reasonable grounds that the person has committed the offence. That is lower than the standard for arrest, which requires a belief as opposed to a suspicion. If those forensic procedures were being undertaken before a person had been arrested, that would occur on a lesser standard than would be required for the person to have been arrested.

Secondly, the bill authorises a constable to order a non-intimate forensic procedure if the suspect does not consent. Again this extension of police powers is contrary to the Law Reform Commission's recommendations and the recommendations of the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee. The Australian Law Reform Commission believes that such procedures should not occur without a court order. It has been argued that, if police are to have such powers, they should only be exercised by more senior police, for example police officers of the rank of sergeant or higher.

Thirdly, the bill applies to indictable offences, which means an offence punishable by imprisonment for more than 12 months. A number of bodies have claimed that this would allow the use of procedures for offences that are really of a minor nature. The Australian Law Reform Commission has recommended that the power to compel forensic procedures should be limited to `serious offences', for example offences punishable by a maximum penalty of five years or more imprisonment. It has been claimed by the Attorney-General's Department that this would confine the bill too narrowly.
Fourthly, it has been suggested that the operation of the bill should be subject to a regular and systematic audit.

Fifthly, it has been argued that the bill should include offences for exercising or threatening to exercise the powers contained in the bill without following the proper procedures. In other words, there should be some offences to deal with those who do not follow the procedures that the bill says ought to be followed. The provision in the bill which removes civil and criminal liability has been the subject of criticism.

Where a suspect resists the taking of a sample, the bill would allow a court to form an adverse inference from that resistance, notwithstanding that the sample was obtained. The Law Council of Australia and the Law Society of New South Wales object to such an inference being drawn.

The bill allows for the taking of swabs and photographs of breasts. It has been argued that it is difficult to imagine an offence where forensic evidence could be obtained by such means. It has been suggested that the bill is likely to disadvantage those in outback areas. In these areas it will take much longer to obtain authorisation and assemble persons to undertake and supervise the procedures. It is argued that this will increase time in custody. While the government has indicated that it intends to introduce amendments that will specify the maximum time limit of four hours for detention, the requirement that `dead time' be discounted will still make those in isolated areas worse off.

While the bill contains specific protections in respect of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, Aboriginal groups have criticised the extent of those safeguards. It has also been noted that in order to be consistent with the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the maximum time for detention should follow the precedent of section 23C(4) of the Crimes Act of 1914 and limit the detention for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to a maximum of two hours.

The bill gives a magistrate a general power to arrest a person for the purposes of giving a sample. In relation to the application of the provision to children, it has been argued that there should be no power to arrest a child unless there has been an attempt to have that child attend by way of summons.

In relation to intimate forensic procedures, the bill provides that `if practicable' the procedure should be carried out by a person of the same sex as the suspect. It has been strongly argued that in the case of children the same sex requirement should be mandatory.

It has been argued that, as the reliability of dental impressions is questionable, the bill ought not to authorise the taking of dental impressions. The Coldrey committee was not persuaded that sufficient justification existed for the taking of dental impressions.

Finally, a number of provisions which specify those persons who may conduct the forensic procedure refer to `an appropriately qualified person'. Such a person is to be determined by regulations. The Law Council of Australia quite properly believes that such an open-ended procedure is inappropriate.

All of these issues have been raised with the Senate committee. They are issues upon which that committee might well be expected to make recommendations. As a result of those deliberations, a number of the issues clearly require further consideration by the government.

As the taking of these procedures is in the hands of the police, it is particularly important to note that the bill does increase police powers in a climate where serious questions are being raised about the exercise of police powers. It is particularly significant that, at a time when even the Australian Federal Police have been the subject of some adverse comment in the Wood royal commission in New South Wales, we are pressing this matter. I do not want to canvass matters in relation to the Australian Federal Police in any detail, except to say that the bill is to be adopted by all jurisdictions. This is a model code for application in New South Wales.

Whatever one might think about allegations of Australian Federal Police potential involvement in corrupt and other activities, the comments that have arisen as a result of the Wood royal commission must serve to raise very considerable doubts in the minds of those who are deliberating on this matter. The unseemly haste is something that this committee needs to note and take into account in its deliberations.

The opposition's approach is not to oppose the bill. Our objections are in relation to the procedural issues that I have outlined. In another place where the government does not have the numbers I suspect that the bill will not receive a speedy passage and that there will be a great deal of time to deliberate in the Senate on the contents of the Senate committee's report.

I suspect that the Senate will not want to conclude its deliberations until the government responds to the Senate committee report. I think that would be a reasonable assumption. If I were one of the officers involved, I would not be sitting on my seat in the Commonwealth car waiting for the bill to go out to Government House to be quickly proclaimed. I think that there is a good deal of water to go under the bridge before we see a bill in its final form.
I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "the debate on the second reading of this Bill be adjourned, and the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the first sitting following 26 October 1995".

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

—The purpose of the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995 is to establish a regime for carrying out forensic procedures during the investigation of Commonwealth offences and for the storage, use and destruction of forensic materials so obtained. The effect of this bill is to extend the powers of police officers to take body samples and prints from—and photographs of—people in custody and people who are suspects but who are not under arrest.

PARA.TAB: The subject of police powers and forensic samples has been dealt with by a number of inquiries in Australia and overseas. The Australian Law Reform Commission looked at the issue in its 1975 report on criminal investigation. The Victorian Consultative Committee on Police Powers of Investigation, also known as the Coldrey committee, published its report on body samples and examinations in 1989. The Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, better known as the Gibbs committee, produced a report dealing with the subject in 1991. Finally, the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission published a report which made recommendations on the subject of forensic procedures in 1994.

In addition to these reports, the subject of police powers and criminal investigation was examined by the New South Wales Law Reform Commission in 1987, the Criminal Law Committee of New Zealand in 1978, the royal commission on criminal procedures in England, and the Law Reform Commission of Canada in 1985. These committees made a range of recommendations regarding the nature of the forensic procedures, the circumstances in which they should be able to be conducted and the protections required to preserve the dignity and civil liberties of the suspect.

The Model Criminal Code Officers Committee of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General—and I hope to goodness that there is no acronym invented for that—then developed model provisions for a forensic procedures bill. Those provisions became the model forensic procedures bill which was released as a draft for consultation and comment in early 1994. Then in January 1995 the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee circulated an amended model forensic procedures bill. While the model bill was welcomed by the Australian Federal Police, it attracted strong criticisms from civil liberties groups.

The bill we are debating today, which was introduced in this House on 29 June this year, was settled by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, but it differs in some respects from the model forensic procedures bill circulated earlier this year. Although the explanatory memorandum states that the bill draws heavily on the recommendations of the Coldrey report, the bill differs in significant respects from the recommendations of that report and of the reports of some of the other committees of inquiry that reported on the issues. I will return to these differences.

The bill would, first, authorise the police to conduct intimate forensic procedures on an adult in lawful custody, either with the informed consent of the adult or, failing that, by order of a magistrate. Secondly, the bill proposes to extend police powers to allow non-intimate forensic procedures to be performed on an adult held in lawful custody, with that person's informed consent, or by order of a police constable or of a magistrate. Thirdly, the bill authorises the police to conduct forensic procedures, both intimate and non-intimate, on adults who have not been taken into lawful custody, either with the informed consent of the suspect or, failing that, by order of a magistrate.

In the case of the use of forensic procedures on a mentally incapable person, the bill proposes that an order be obtained from a magistrate, whether the person is held in custody or not. Similarly, the bill would allow the use of forensic procedures on a child under 18, whether or not held in lawful custody, but only on the order of a magistrate. The forensic procedures described in the bill vary from the taking of body samples, such as hair and saliva, to taking dental impressions and fingerprints, and include the taking of photographs of parts of the body.

Although the bill was introduced into and has not yet passed through this House, on 28 August this year the Senate referred the bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. The Senate committee was due to report on 25 September 1995. That date was then extended until 18 October and the report date was again extended, from Tuesday, until 26 October, which is Thursday next week.

In the light of the many concerns raised about the bill in its public hearings, the Senate committee is likely to recommend a number of changes to the bill. The government will need time to respond to the committee's recommendations.

This bill makes very important changes to police powers and is designed as a model to be adopted by other jurisdictions. It is therefore important that this House should be debating the legislation after the committee has tabled its report and after the government has responded. At the very least, this House should have the benefit of the committee's recommendations.

The minister did in fact agree to that, as was pointed out by the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) this morning and as was pointed out in the debate on Tuesday, 17 October, on the motion to refer this bill to the Main Committee. I urge the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) to ensure that debate of this bill is adjourned in accordance with the motion moved by the member for Berowra until after the committee has tabled its report on the proposed legislation.

Although the bill is not opposed, the coalition does have a great many concerns with the detail of the bill, especially with the issue of the appropriate balance between the needs of law enforcement and the protection of civil liberties. This concern is reflected in the differences between the provisions of the bill and the recommendations of the various reports which led to the bill. It can also be seen clearly from concerns which have been raised publicly concerning the bill, both before the Senate committee and elsewhere.

One of the differences between the bill and some of the inquiry recommendations is that the bill will permit police to conduct forensic procedures on a person before arrest and without the person's consent. This is contrary to the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee. It is a significant extension of police powers, and I will say a bit more about that.

The bill also proposes to allow the police to conduct non-intimate forensic procedures on a person held in custody without the suspect's consent to the procedure and on the order of a police constable. This, too, is contrary to the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee.

By its inclusion within the definition of an intimate forensic procedure, the bill will give police the power to obtain dental impressions. The Coldrey committee recommended against giving police this power, on the basis of the unreliability of bite mark evidence. Similarly, the Coldrey committee noted that hair samples do not provide a reliable means of identifying a suspect, and that about 100 strands are required for testing. However, the bill would permit the taking of a sample of pubic hair as an intimate forensic procedure and the taking of a sample of any other type of hair as a non-intimate forensic procedure.

I propose now to refer to some of the concerns expressed about the detailed provisions of the bill. I cannot, of course, refer to the conclusions reached by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee as the result of its inquiry but, as I said, I anticipate that the Senate committee will have regard to those concerns and that its report will recommend amendment of the bill.

As I have already noted, the definition of `suspect' in connection with an indictable offence includes persons in addition to those charged with the offence and those summonsed to appear in court in relation to the offence. It includes a person whom a constable suspects on reasonable grounds has committed the indictable offence. This is a lesser test than that required before there will be grounds for arresting a person. To restrict the use of forensic procedures to arrested persons would be to build in an important procedural safeguard of the civil liberties of the suspect. In order to arrest a suspect, the constable must have reasonable grounds to believe—not suspect but believe—that the person committed the offence.

The bill requires the constable to satisfy himself or herself as to a number of matters before he or she can ask a suspect to consent to a forensic procedure. Clearly, the reason for conducting a forensic procedure on a suspect is that the police believe that, by doing so, they will obtain evidence that will assist in their investigations and in securing a conviction. Thus, one of the matters on which the constable must satisfy himself or herself is that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the forensic procedure is likely to produce evidence tending to confirm or disprove that the suspect committed a relevant offence. But the bill defines `relevant offence' to mean not only the offence in relation to which the person is a suspect but also any other indictable offence in respect of which the evidence likely to be obtained as a result of a proposed forensic procedure carried out on the suspect is likely to have probative value.

The drafting of this definition is unsatisfactory because its application gives an ambiguous result. For example, in its present form, it would allow the police to conduct a forensic procedure on a person for the purpose of gathering evidence in relation to an offence which the person is not suspected of having committed, in order to prove or disprove that the person committed that offence.

Similarly, the present wording of the provision allows a magistrate to order a forensic procedure if he or she is satisfied that it would produce evidence tending to confirm or disprove that the suspect committed an offence which the person is not suspected of having committed. This is clearly unsatisfactory and I urge the minister to make the appropriate amendments so as to remove the uncertainty that this provision creates.

The bill provides no right of appeal for a suspect against a magistrate's order allowing a forensic procedure to be carried out. In my view, there ought to be some appeal mechanism in order to ensure that the individual's rights are protected.

The bill prescribes the matters as to which the constable must be satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, before he or she can ask a suspect to consent to a forensic procedure. These matters include considering whether the request is justified in all the circumstances. To decide this, the constable is required to balance the public interest in obtaining evidence against the opposing public interest in upholding the physical integrity of the suspect. In order to conduct this balancing test, the bill requires the constable to have regard to a number of matters set out in the bill. Surprisingly, while the list of matters includes such things as the cultural background of the suspect, the bill does not require that the constable take account of a person's religious beliefs, if relevant, when he determines where the public interest lies. Some forensic procedures, such as the taking of blood, may directly infringe on a person's religious beliefs. In my view, a religious objection to a forensic procedure is a matter that constables should take into account when determining public interest.

The bill provides that, when deciding whether to ask an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander suspect to consent to a forensic procedure or whether to make a constable's order in the absence of consent, a constable is required to ascertain the customary beliefs of the suspect. It has been pointed out that it is difficult to imagine less favourable circumstances for a constable to discover a person's cultural beliefs than during a criminal investigation into that person and while considering whether to ask or order that person to submit to forensic procedures. It has been suggested that it may be better to express the duty on magistrates and constables as a duty to ask the suspect if there was anything they wished to put before the magistrate or constable in relation to their customary beliefs.

Before a constable can ask an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander suspect to consent to a forensic procedure, the constable is required to notify a representative of an Aboriginal legal aid organisation, unless the suspect has arranged for a lawyer to be present. This provision fails to recognise the difficulties that arise in some places, including, in particular, my own state, Western Australia. Aboriginal people often live in remote communities where Aboriginal legal aid representatives do not live and where it would take many hours to get the services of such a person. In the meantime, important forensic material may be lost. The need for the inclusion of this requirement is difficult to understand in a case of non-intimate and non-invasive forensic procedures such as taking a photo of a wound.

It is noted that the constable must, in addition, inform the suspect of a list of matters set out in the bill. These include the purpose of the forensic procedure, the offence in relation to which the constable wants the procedure carried out, the fact that any evidence might be used as evidence in court against the suspect and the suspect's right to refuse to consent to the procedure.

The bill not only authorises the police to carry out both intimate and non-intimate forensic procedures in specified circumstances, it also empowers the police to use reasonable force to carry out the procedure. However, the bill does not authorise the police to take a sample of hair by removing the root of the hair, nor to carry out a forensic procedure in a `cruel, inhuman or degrading manner'. In my view, the police should not be authorised to use force to conduct an intimate forensic procedure on a suspect who has not been arrested.

Nor does the bill make it clear who will be conducting the forensic procedure. The table in the bill sets out the different procedures and who may conduct them. In all but two cases, the procedure need not be conducted by a medical practitioner or a nurse, but it may be conducted by an `appropriately qualified person'. An `appropriately qualified person' is defined in the bill as someone qualified as prescribed by regulations.

In Western Australia, forensic scientists are involved in the collection of samples from suspects under state legislation. Any regulations to be made under the bill should include forensic scientists as appropriately qualified persons. But by far the preferable alternative would be for the qualifications to be set out in the bill.

The category of persons who can undertake intimate body searches should be strictly limited by the parliament. Some of the forensic procedures, particularly those defined as `intimate procedures', are so intrusive that it is important that the parliament has a say in who is to be authorised to conduct them. In this context, it is not at all appropriate that the meaning of `appropriately qualified person' be left to be fleshed out by regulations as yet unmade.

The bill also empowers a person who is authorised to conduct a forensic procedure to ask another person, who need not be qualified, to assist him or her with the procedure. This provision causes me some concern. If there is a need to have assistance in any instance, the choice of a helper should be restricted.

Further, in all procedures except the taking of a hand, foot, finger or toe print, the suspect is entitled to request the presence of a medical practitioner, and in some cases a dentist, of his or her own choice. However, the bill does not allow the suspect to have the procedure conducted by their own doctor or dentist. To have one's own doctor conduct a specified procedure would make the process much more acceptable. If conducted in this way, but in the presence of the investigating constable, it is difficult to see what objection could be taken by the police.

The bill provides that if there is a breach of or a failure to comply with the procedures in the bill, and the suspect objects to the admissibility of the evidence in court, then the court has a discretion to admit the evidence. In my view, there is a strong argument for rejecting all evidence that is tainted by illegality. Any evidence obtained from a forensic procedure conducted in breach of the provisions of the bill should be required, except for very good reason, to be treated as inadmissible.

If the bill is designed to ensure a balance between the two aims of prosecuting offenders and protecting the civil liberties of the individual, then a failure to observe any of those very detailed provisions unbalances the scales and can lead to an injustice. This parliament should be vigilant to avoid that possibility and I urge the minister to amend the bill accordingly.

The bill also permits the taking of blood samples after a person has been convicted of a serious offence and a court has directed that the person give a blood sample. In deciding whether to make the order, the court must take into account the seriousness of the circumstances surrounding the offence, the gravity of the offence and whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person may have committed some other serious offence or may commit some other serious offence in the future. In this respect, this bill makes unreasonable demands on the courts. While the court may conceivably have grounds for believing that the person may have committed some other serious offence, the court cannot really decide that a person may commit some other serious offence in the future. Due to the unpredictability of human nature, the courts are not equipped to judge which convicted criminals will re-offend and which will be rehabilitated.

Given that a constable who is investigating an offence can order that a forensic procedure be carried out on a suspect without consent, it is arguable that the bill should include a reporting requirement on the exercise of the power. An annual report should set out the number of applications for orders for forensic procedures, the number of orders made and an assessment of how the procedure is working.

It has been said that the widening of police powers to take body samples would create a situation in which the police become more careless with the proper traditional methods of investigation. It is said that there is the potential for abuse. For example, a lazy or corrupt investigator may be tempted to put a hair from a suspect at the scene of a crime in order to secure a conviction. It is difficult to assess that risk, but any reporting mechanism should enable some assessment to be made after some experience of the use of the powers.

The bill exempts from civil and criminal liability any person who carries out or helps to carry out a forensic procedure in the circumstances set out in the relevant clause of the bill. These circumstances are generally that the person acted in good faith and believed, on reasonable grounds, either that the suspect had given informed consent or that a court order had been made. In this respect, that person will be often entirely acting in reliance upon a police constable who may have made the order. In my view, this exclusion from liability is very wide. It gives the individual insufficient protection against unjustified testing.

In any event, it is questionable that such a range of forensic procedures need be authorised. A blood sample can provide the best DNA evidence, as well as blood type and other markers. The results of blood tests can be cross-matched with other body fluids at the scene of a crime. It is not clear to me why, if parliament gives police compulsory power to obtain blood samples, they should also be authorised to take saliva or hair. There is no limit on the range which may be applied to an individual and, no doubt, police will seek to use the range in each case.

A person may be arrested for the purpose of being brought before the court for an application by the police for a forensic search order. There is, in the original form of the bill, no time limit on this period of detention. I understand from the second reaching speech delivered by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) that there will be a limit. It is unclear if state bail legislation will apply to a person detained under this provision. The only remedy available where a detained person has not been arrested appears to be the common law action of habeas corpus.

These concerns reflect community concerns with the provisions of the bill and amply justify the Senate inquiry, and also amply justified an inquiry which was not conducted by the House committee, and I commend the amendment to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate that has taken place in the Main Committee in relation to the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995 amply indicates that the minister has, in my view, improperly rushed into this place to force the House of Representatives to have a debate on a bill precipitately, particularly when there are obviously very widespread concerns throughout the Australian community in relation to both the substance and the detail of this particular bill. We understand that the minister at one stage was happy to defer this debate until after the Senate Legal and Constitution Affairs Legislation Committee had in fact reported, but apparently the report of the Senate committee has been postponed somewhat and the result is that the minister now wishes the debate which is currently taking place to in fact occur.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate, because it is obvious, given the very great interest from the Australian community in the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995, that the Senate committee will make a number of recommendations for change. Clearly, the law needs to take advantage of technological advances. It is important to always get a balance between the rights of the subject and, indeed, the community's need to ensure that people who have committed offences are in fact convicted of them.

This particular bill is one which we have discussed widely in the coalition. We have spoken to a large number of groups in the community and while, on balance, we are not opposed to the principle of the bill, we do have very grave concern about some elements of the detail. When one looks at the various submissions—and there have been at least 20 submissions made to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee—it is obvious that very widespread and well-respected people right across the nation have expressed their concern about one or other element of the bill.

It is unfortunate that the minister has chosen to treat the House of Representatives with contempt by forcing the House of Representatives to debate this bill when it is obvious that the Senate will be looking very closely at the government's response to the report which will be handed down on 26 October 1995 by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. Clearly, the Senate will hand down its report, and the government will consider the elements of that report and will come back with a response. It is not unreasonable to expect that the minister will accept a considerable number of the recommendations of the Senate committee, particularly if those recommendations are made unanimously or by an overwhelming majority.

In a sense, the debate we are having in the Main Committee today could be futile because, while we could canvass many of the submissions made before the Senate committee, the reality is that the bill that is ultimately carried by the parliament might well be quite different from the bill which is currently before us for debate. Therefore, I think the minister's actions in precipitating this early debate are unwise, to say the least, and treat the House of Representatives with contempt.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) mentioned another matter and that was that the bill could well have been referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, a committee of which I have the privilege to be a member. This committee has absolutely no work at the moment. It is a committee that is controlled by the government, is chaired by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) and has a very large number of members with great experience in the legal and constitutional field but, sadly, for some reason the government appears to be unwilling to refer any legislation to it.

The government seeks to make mileage out of emphasising the importance of the House of Representatives as the people's house and as the house where governments are made and broken. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) refers to senators as `unrepresentative swill' and yet we find that the minister is preferring to have these bills sent to the Senate committee rather than to a committee of the House of Representatives. It is probably an indictment that, since Federation, House of Representatives committees have not worked as well as Senate committees.

The minister now has a committee which has produced a number of very effective reports, including one relating to the child sex tourism legislation, yet the minister is not prepared to allow the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to express a view on the bill.

We now find that we are debating the legislation. This debate, to a certain extent, will be superseded by the report of the Senate committee and by the debate in the Senate. Ultimately, if this legislation is passed in some form by the other place, the minister will come back and undoubtedly accept the amendments. The minister has put the cart before the horse in putting this particular legislation before the committee at this time. It is obvious, when one is dealing with such important legislation, that both houses of the parliament should be allowed to have a full debate on the terms of the bill which is likely to become law.

In Australia at the moment there is a concern about having a balance between police powers and the rights of the individual and this is a bill which significantly increases police powers. Many people are happy with the format of the bill. Some people are happy with the substance of the bill, some people are opposed to it and some people, while supporting the thrust of the bill, are concerned about the detail. The more than 20 submissions which have been received by the Senate committee weigh quite a lot and they will obviously be weighing on the mind of the Senate committee. Those 20 submissions put forward a number of very important points which the minister ought to be considering before seeking to push the bill through the Main Committee.

This important piece of legislation seeks to amend the Crimes Act to enable police to take body samples, such as fingerprints and blood, from suspects in criminal cases. All of us want to see as much uniformity in the criminal law as possible. We are aiming to establish a model criminal code, and it is hoped that the provisions of this bill will be incorporated as part of a national criminal code so that people in one part of the country will be bound by criminal laws similar to those in other parts of the country.

That is another reason the government should have looked very closely at its provisions before forcing the House of Representatives Main Committee to discuss them at this time. Across the nation we have differing rules relating to forensic procedures, and it is appropriate that we should endeavour to draw all of these together and find some common ground. I think the minister's precipitate action will probably prevent the uniform approach that we all seek.

The bill before the parliament is based on the model provisions developed by the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The model provisions were the subject of consultation across Australia. The final form of the bill was determined, admittedly, by the standing committee but there are amendments which will be introduced, and I believe that the House ought to have the opportunity to deal with them.

The bill deals with, firstly, intimate forensic procedures and, secondly, non-intimate forensic procedures. Intimate forensic procedures include the taking of blood, the taking of dental impressions, and procedures involving genital areas and, in the case of women, breasts. Non-intimate procedures include the taking of fingerprints, the taking of samples of non-pubic hair and other less intrusive procedures not involving genital areas.

The scheme of the bill is to impose greater controls over the taking of intimate forensic procedures. The bill draws, quite appropriately, a range of distinctions among those adults who are in custody or not in custody, people who are not competent or capable, and persons who are deemed to be under age. There have been a number of submissions made concerning those particular matters.

The bill stipulates those people who may carry out a particular forensic procedure and, depending on the procedures, those persons may be a medical practitioner or a dentist, a nurse, a dental technician or someone else who, in a particular case, is deemed to be appropriately qualified. With respect to most forensic procedures the bill entitles the suspect to request the presence of a medical practitioner or dentist of the suspect's choice. There are some additional safeguards included in the bill with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

As I indicated before, some people have fully supported the bill, some have partly supported it and others have expressed outright opposition, which is another matter the minister should have taken on board before endeavouring to again use this parliament as a sausage machine. I believe that the thrust of the bill is not able to be objected to, but I share some of the concerns expressed by those who made submissions to the Senate committee.

Other speakers have pointed out that a wide range of concerns have been expressed. In fact, Mr Tony Morris QC, one of Australia's leading Queen's Counsel, has expressed a number of concerns about aspects of the bill. My view is that whenever Mr Morris expresses concerns the government really ought to look very closely and ought not to force a debate prior to considering those concerns at length and the reaction of the Senate committee to those concerns.

The Queensland Law Society Inc. also made a submission. I would like to quote from a letter to Ms Anne Twomey, the Secretary of the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee, from Mr Scott Carter, who is the solicitor to the Queensland Law Society. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: This society has many concerns regarding the proposed legislation which will permit citizens to be subjected to procedures which are invasive, offensive and in many cases intimidatory. This may occur when the citizens concerned have not been charged with any offence and where there is insufficient evidence available to warrant any charge or to sustain any prosecution.

The Queensland Law Society then went on with a very detailed submission which, again, will be taken into consideration by the Senate committee. But, in this place, we are not able to look at the Senate response to these submissions received by the committee from the Queensland Law Society and by the other people who have seen fit to make submissions to that committee.

PARA.TAB: The Law Society of New South Wales was quite concerned about the bill and, indeed, there was a letter written to the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee by the president of that society, a person known as Mr Maurie Stack. He said that the Law Society of New South Wales has a number of very great concerns in relation to this bill. He pointed out that the society opposes the taking of samples from persons who have not been arrested. He pointed out that the society opposes the breadth of procedures proposed to be authorised by the bill.

The committee also calls for at least equal, if not greater, protections for persons subject to forensic procedures than exist for persons detained for questioning. It calls for the inclusion of a requirement that a judge warn the jury about any evidence which was collected in breach of the bill. It seeks either the removal of any possible adverse inference or direction or the restriction of any such comments to situations where no sample was obtained. It submits that evidence of resistance should be inadmissible or, alternatively, restricted to situations where no sample was obtained and it seeks the inclusion in the bill of a requirement that police officers and magistrates must warn the detainee of the consequences of resistance. It opposes the removal of the current requirement that the fingerprints of juveniles charged with an offence may be taken only as a result of a court order. It calls for the substitution of supplier to be made available to remove any ambiguity about the right of the detained person to obtain copies or samples of evidence. That is from section 23YG.

So, whichever way you look at it, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a complicated bill. It is an important bill. It is a bill which seeks to take advantage of advances in technology. On the other hand, it is a piece of legislation about which very many people have expressed great concern. The Bulletin, on 14 February 1995, quite accurately expressed the debate which was taking place. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The parliamentary debate is already shaping along established lines between the civil libertarians, who argue that taking samples from a suspect is a potential infringement of privacy and individual rights, and those who argue that police need such tools to carry out their investigations properly.
The Bulletin went on to say:
The Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr, says the planned federal law has a built-in safeguard; police must apply for a court order to take samples from suspects who do not give their consent.

PARA.TAB: `What is required is a balance between the civil liberties of the individual and the requirement for police to have adequate investigative powers,' Kerr said when he announced the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have a situation where people on this side of the House and on the other side of House agree that we need to have a balance. Of course, our responsibility is to get that balance right.

PARA.TAB: The government, by forcing the debate at this time, has deprived this House of the opportunity of getting that balance right. We could debate this particular bill all day. We could argue along the lines of the 20-odd submissions made to the Senate committee, but what really ought to happen is that the government should take this bill away. The government ought not to deal with this bill until such time as the Senate committee has reported, until such time as the Attorney-General's Department and the minister have had the opportunity to absorb the contents of that Senate report. Then it should release a response to that particular report for public viewing. Unfortunately, the government has decided to proceed, notwithstanding the fact that the Senate committee has not reported. The Senate committee will report in December, which is not very far away.

This legislation has been around for a long time. Another two months delay is not going to be a major problem. What the government should do, in my view, is to wait. It should accept the suggestion of the opposition that the legislation not be proceeded with until after the committee has reported and the government has responded to the committee. Once that has happened, we will then see amendments to the bill and this House will be able to debate the amended bill, which would be along the lines of a bill more likely to be carried by both houses of the parliament.

It is unfortunate that the minister has failed to take the advice that we have given him. The result will be that he has deprived the House of Representatives of the opportunity of debating in full a bill which will ultimately become law. I think the minister, as a minister of the Crown in a government which purports to push the rights of the House of Representatives, has once again been exposed as being a hypocritical person.

I am pleased to see the honourable member for Banks come into the chamber, because he is the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I invite him before the Committee this morning to tell the Committee and to tell the minister in this public forum that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs would have been more than happy to receive the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he nodded.

—I think he did nod and he might have even said yes. The fact of the matter is that we have a good committee, we have an effective committee, we have a committee that is widely representative—a committee that the government controls—and yet, despite that, the minister is not prepared to give that committee any work at all. The committee in the Senate is burdened down with work and that has delayed the handing down of the Senate report. What the minister could have done would have been to refer this bill to the House committee. Because he has not given us any work in recent times, the committee could have processed the bill quickly. He could have had our advice, he could have had our suggested amendments and, indeed, he then could have amended the bill and we could have had a full debate here on what would be the final form of the bill. Instead, what is going to happen is that this debate will proceed to the other place, there will be very many amendments made to the bill and the bill will return to the House of Representatives ultimately. The minister will accept many of those amendments and they will be pumped through.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the minister, by refusing to refer this bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, has deprived this House, the people's house, the house of which he is supposed to be the champion, of the opportunity to debate the actual form of legislation which most probably will become the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Act 1995 after it has been through both houses of the parliament. I invite the member for Banks now to rise in this place and to tell us whether our committee could have handled this matter and whether he approves of what the minister has done. I think that what the minister has done is most unfortunate and is most derogatory to the position of the House of Representatives in this Australian parliament.
