DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 28 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is part of a global network of legislation, with the goal of protecting biological diversity and maintaining ecological processes and systems.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments will enhance the extent to which Australia discharges its obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) of wild fauna and flora and the Convention on Biological Diversity. The amendments will provide an improved administrative framework, strengthen measures against illegal wildlife trafficking, and make the Australian Nature Conservation Agency's service to client groups more effective. They will also support a national approach to the conservation of Australia's biodiversity and improve arrangements for regulating the commercial use of wildlife.

The proposed amendments have been developed after extensive consultations with state and territory governments, and industry and non-government organisations, and are in accord with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment.

The changes have largely arisen from recommendations of the Ley report which reviewed the act, having particular regard to Australia's obligations under CITES. The proposed amendments will implement appendix III of CITES, relating to species identified by a party as under regulation to prevent or restrict exploitation, and needing the cooperation of others in the control of trade. They will also enable a more flexible approach to controlling private non-commercial trade in species identified under appendix II of CITES, species identified as, although not endangered, requiring trade regulation.

A number of wildlife export industries in Australia are subject to the act, which currently provides for the establishment of management and controlled specimens programs, the development of which is undertaken in close consultation with state and territory agencies. The amendments will include the requirement that any proposals for the commercial utilisation and international trade in native wildlife are subject to appropriate legislative and regulatory regimes in the relevant state or territory. Management programs may only be approved where the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories is satisfied that to ensure protection of the species, appropriate regulatory measures, monitoring and assessment procedures are in place for the proposed harvesting activity.

Management programs will be subject to time limitations, as it is vital that harvesting of wild native plants and animals is reviewed on a regular basis. Therefore, the amendments will establish a maximum period of five years between such reviews, with the flexibility to establish shorter periods should it be considered necessary.

Through the introduction of special conditions for permits for export of native animals under inter-zoological garden transfer, Australian zoos will be better able to manage their animal populations. The well-developed Australasian species management program will be assisted by these measures, which will also facilitate participation in international breeding programs involving endangered species.

The risks of detection and prosecution to those associated with wildlife smuggling will increase as a combined result of improved administrative measures and enforcement efforts. Continuation of cooperative work undertaken by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, the Australian Customs Service, state and federal police, and state wildlife agencies will ensure that these changes are effective. Overall, they will improve operating efficiency without compromising the protection of wildlife and the Australian environment.

The proposals include improved enforcement powers of inspectors appointed under the act by strengthening powers of seizure, improving powers of search of premises and conveyances and providing powers to conduct frisk searches of suspect persons, enabling seizure of specimens. These provisions are consistent with the Criminal Code Bill 1994 and the recently amended Crimes Act 1914, while taking into account the rights of the individual. Penalties have also been made consistent with Commonwealth policy regarding introduction of penalty units.

In addition to the substantial penalties currently available for illegally importing and exporting wildlife, the amendments propose a new offence. Any person illegally importing or exporting live animals may be subject to a potential two-year imprisonment term, if found guilty of cruel treatment to the animal. This will ensure that the treatment of the animals involved in such crimes is subject to consideration by the courts.

The government is also concerned that the establishment of self-sustaining populations of exotic birds in the Australian wild could have disastrous effects on native wildlife populations. Further, it may only take one bird which is infected with an exotic disease, and which has been smuggled into Australia, to contaminate thousands of aviary held or wild native birds. These are serious risks which require a comprehensive approach.

A central measure in the bill, to address these concerns, is the introduction of a national exotic bird registration scheme. The scheme was developed in close consultation with the aviculture industry, bird keepers and the states and territories. Registration will provide an inventory of exotic birds currently housed in Australia that have environmental or pest potential, and those that are endangered internationally.

A national inventory created under the scheme will provide an agreed list of exotic birds in Australia that will enable, for the first time, the means to properly manage exotic birds. Whilst providing a national focus, the proposed amendments allow the states and territories the flexibility to impose additional measures if they so desire. The scheme will support and assist the legal trade in exotic birds within Australia. The uncertainty and risks associated with the purchase of many birds will be substantially reduced, by eliminating doubt as to the legal origin of the bird.

An advisory committee to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories will be established to examine the ongoing effectiveness of the registration scheme and to provide advice on proposed variations to the list of birds proposed for registration. This committee will comprise representatives of government, conservation, and private and professional aviculture. As agreed to in the Senate, the amendment bill will ensure that any one interest group does not constitute a majority of the members of the Exotic Birds Committee.

In addition, two other changes were made to the amendment bill in the Senate. The first referred to the requirement for the Australian Nature Conservation Agency to provide reports on permits and authorities issued to be produced at least every 12 months, and the second removed from the amendment bill those sections which would allow the import of appendix 1 specimens subject to CITES quota, such as leopard skins. The amendment bill also proposes tighter controls on the export of birds as household pets by providing for a limit of two birds that may be taken out of Australia by a person leaving to take up permanent residence overseas.

Additionally, through arrangements being developed under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, international cooperation to stem the illegal wildlife trade has become more effective. Australia has an excellent international reputation for its positive involvement in conservation issues, and will be further extending its support to other countries in this respect, with the creation of a new offence whereby it will be illegal to import wildlife specimens contrary to the conservation laws of a foreign country, where a breach of the overseas law involves trade with Australia and where the foreign country requests assistance. This will enable Australia to assist with international enforcement of wildlife laws of other countries.

The environmental problems of the globe, which include a range of threats to biodiversity and the survival of many species of wildlife, will only be addressed through national and international cooperative measures. This government is providing leadership and support in meeting the national and international challenge of protecting biological diversity and maintaining ecological processes and systems.

The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 is a step forward in meeting this challenge and it is a further example of the government's commitment to ensuring an ecologically sustainable future. I commend the bill to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to address the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 as the subject of the bill is a particular interest of mine. As the bill has already gone through the Senate and the actual details of the bill have been addressed by the shadow minister for the environment, Senator Rod Kemp, I shall not go into these details. I will address the bill in a wider, general context and I will discuss some of the principles behind the bill where the government is failing. There is a lot more which should be done in this area.

PARA.TAB: Australia is in a unique position inasmuch as it is a single country continent and has unique flora and fauna. Australia's unique flora and fauna have evolved in a particular ecological system which does not—except, obviously, for things like migratory birds and fishes which have become part of this ecological system—allow for too much interruption. When we bring exotic species into Australia, we do so at considerable threat to this environment. This bill seeks in part to address this situation, but it does not go far enough.

The bill looks at the importation and exportation of both endangered species and other species. When I read the list of the species that we are allowed to import, I was delighted to find that one of the species is a fowl known as Gallus gallus. It is this very importation of birds that I address.

Australia imported exotic birds—I am talking about birds such as parrots which were imported for aviarians—until the 1950s but stopped importation because of the possible danger to the Australian bird population. Australia did not begin importing exotic birds again until 1989 when the regulations changed. The regulations were changed because of pressure from aviculturists. The aviculturists had a genetic stock which was becoming inbred and they wanted to bring in aviary birds from overseas to add to their stock.

The desire of aviculturists to bring in new stock is a legitimate desire but it is one that does not warrant the risk that is taken in doing so. This is because when permission was granted for these exotic birds to be brought in we simply did not have the knowledge about exotic parrot and budgerigar diseases that we have, for instance, about the diseases that affect poultry. A lot of money has gone into researching the sorts of diseases—such as Newcastle disease—which affect poultry, simply because of the commercial impact such diseases would have on our poultry industry. However, this research has never been carried out with parrot diseases.

Consequently, after 1989 when we lifted the ban on the importation of these exotic species, when the first shipments of budgerigars were brought in many deaths occurred amongst the budgerigar population. The budgerigars were given antibiotics but, as with antibiotics in other situations, the budgerigars overseas were becoming immune to the antibiotics. Consequently, when the budgerigars were brought into Australia, Australian budgerigars picked up the same viruses and the Australian birds are now also becoming resistant to antibiotics. This situation is having quite an effect on Australia's budgerigar population.

There is now a range of diseases in Australia's budgerigar population which has never been seen before. Polyama virus is one of the diseases which we simply did not see in Australia before the shipments of budgerigars arrived after 1989.

But of even greater concern is what is happening with the parrot population. In 1992 we had the first shipment of parrots after the change of regulations in 1989. The requirements of these shipment are that the parrots remain in quarantine in England until they are shipped out here; they then go into quarantine in Australia. In 1993 a further shipment was made. While these parrots were in quarantine in England, a green-winged macaw died, as did a lutino elegance.

Despite this, the whole shipload was brought to Australia, where a second green-winged macaw became ill. It was dosed up with antibiotics and then released to the person who had ordered it, who happened to be a very reputable aviarist from Grafton; it was fortunate that it was somebody of such high repute. But the bird died seven weeks later.

There is some mystery as to what happened when that bird died. There have been accusations that there were insufficient investigations. There was no request for the isolation of the other birds that were in the cage with the green-winged macaw. This has caused concern amongst people who believe that it was at best premature, and at worst foolhardy, to begin importing exotic birds into Australia.

One of the arguments that was given for doing this—and it does sound like a fairly convincing argument—is that prior to their importation there was quite a big trade in illegal birds. Birds were carried in jackets, with the eggs in the pockets. The aviarists put to the government that if the birds were allowed in legally this would cut down the illegal trade.

My first objection to that argument is that, when you have birds such as the green-winged macaw that are selling for $20,000 a pair, you are not going to cut down the illegal trade. There is too much money to be made out of it.

Secondly, rather than cutting it down, this provided an opportunity for the laundering of illegal birds. As long as new birds were coming in, they could be passed off as part of the progeny of that new bird shipment.

One of the reasons for the introduction of these regulations is to deal with that problem. To prevent the laundering of the illegal birds, there is a much stricter registration scheme on exotic birds that are brought in legally . However, I suspect that this is far from foolproof. Even if it has, and does, cut down the illegal importation of birds to a certain extent, it does not remove the risks that importation poses to Australia's native bird population. I certainly do not want to be taken as saying anything in favour of smugglers, but eggs are much less likely to be carriers of disease than the birds themselves. Our native bird population is at less risk from smugglers than from the legal activities of bird importers.

These birds are kept in aviaries, and we only need one infected bird to come in and infect other birds in that aviary. Some of these birds are the Typhoid Marys of the bird population: they carry diseases which they themselves do not show any signs of, but they carry it to others. An example of this is the South American conures, which carry Pacheo diseases. They do not show the effects themselves; they simply pass it to other birds. Australian parrots are very susceptible to South American diseases.

Exotic birds can bring in other diseases. The Rio virus is brought in by the South African grey parrots. While we already have pox virus in Australia, it is a different strain from that which is coming in with the exotic birds. Our birds are very susceptible to that strain. I do not want to say that we are infecting our bird population at this stage, because we are not, but the danger does exist. While we continue to bring exotic birds into Australia simply so that aviarists can increase their genetic stock we are putting our wildlife population at risk. We only need one bird to infect other birds in an aviary and then one of those infected birds to get out into the wild population or an aviarist who is not as careful as some to take a dead bird out of his aviary and throw it on a rubbish heap; that would be enough for a disease to get out and infect the bird population.

This matter is of considerable concern to me. Although I am happy to see that we are tightening up on the registration of exotic birds, I still think the basic problem remains. I am yet to be convinced that the risk we are taking with our bird population is worth it, simply so the aviarists can have a wider stock in their aviaries. I cannot see where the risk benefit is.

If people really want to do this, I urge the government to look at zoo breeding. Zoos can bring in eggs under strictly controlled conditions. They can then breed them and sell them as a money making enterprise to the aviarists who want a wider stock of birds. This would seem to me to solve both problems. It would allow aviarists to have their birds and it would guarantee the safety of our bird population.

While I support what the bill is doing in regard to birds, I would like us to have a moratorium on the importation of exotic birds to see whether we can do it some other way without putting our bird life at risk.

When the bill was mooted, the World Wide Fund for Nature suggested that some amendments should be made to it, and I support them. I note those amendments have not been put in. They were amendments of a fairly minor nature. We will not be putting the amendments today, but I hope that at some later stage either the present government or a coalition government would have a look at them. Their concern is about the use of the CITES species, the endangered species, in herbal medicines.

These medicines are based on the mythological characteristics of some animals. Leopards, tigers and deer musk are used and seem to have magical properties. Tiger penis is also supposed to be fairly good for something. I am sure the gentlemen here would know much more about that.

There is quite a trade in these medicines, especially amongst people whose families originally came from Asia. While there is prohibition against use and a penalty for possession, the penalty is exactly the same if a person has them in their possession for sale. Part of the World Wide Fund for Nature, the Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce, has pointed out that we need a larger penalty for people who are importing these parts of endangered species and selling them as medicines. To have an elderly gentleman who is using deer musk in his house receive the same penalty as a person who has imported and is selling medicines does not make any sense at all. There should be a much greater penalty for sale.
At some stage I would like to see the government or the succeeding coalition government introduce those amendments and add them to the bill.

Finally, on the same principle as I espoused earlier, we are allowing far too much into this country—not only birds but also aquarium fish and fish bait. Recently there was a suggestion on the Four Corners program that the death of pilchards around Australia might have been caused by the importation of frozen pilchard bait for the tuna fish industry.

The tuna industry denied this and said that it was not possible as the bait had been tested. I would be inclined to believe the people in the tuna industry because they take their industry very seriously. But the point is that something did get in and infect that fish. While ever we import frozen bait—because we cannot supply it ourselves—and other types of fish, we will be putting our fish and our waterways at risk.

Every day when I leaf through the papers I find headlines such as `Carp puts trout fishery in danger', `Exotic fish threat to Lake Eucumbene', `Fish pose threat to Queensland water supplies'—that is the exotic tropical fish tilapia—and so on. We are standing on the edge of a potential catastrophe by allowing these imports to get into our rivers. We saw what happened in the Murray with the carp. Our rivers are simply not set up to include these exotic fish.

It is not only with marine and animal life that we have a problem; we also have a problem with introduced plants, especially grasses. This issue was brought to my attention when I went around Australia with the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Many of the weeds that now infest our countryside were brought in as grasses to be used in agriculture, to bind banks and other things. These grasses have now got out of control and are taking over some of our native grasslands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paterson's curse.

—Yes. What is really disturbing is that it is still happening and we do not have the controls that we should have on the importation of a lot of these seeds and grasses. There was an article by Julian Cribb on imported plants in the Australian of 21 February 1994. I found that article absolutely fascinating because it provided statistics on what has been happening. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a scientific study showing many supposedly useful plants allowed into Australia in the past 40 years have proved to be devastating weeds.
These are not plants that have got in illegally; they are plants that have been allowed in. The article continued:
Of 463 alien plants introduced to northern Australia since 1947, only 21 proved useful—but 60 became weeds. Of the useful plants, 17 later became weeds also, according to the research by CSIRO.
It further stated:
Of the country's 220 worst exotic weeds, almost half had been introduce for a purpose.
That we continue to allow these grasses and plants into Australia is, I think, extraordinarily dangerous and extraordinarily foolhardy. This should be looked at by whichever party is in government.

PARA.TAB: The environment committee recommended in its report on biological diversity that this should happen, and I cannot remember the name of the report. We made a strong recommendation that there be much stricter controls on grasses and plants brought into Australia for agricultural purposes. The information that I have been given is that that is not happening and that there is certainly a very strong lack of good controls. As I said at the beginning, we are so vulnerable in this area because of the way that our environment has evolved with its own ecosystem which simply cannot tolerate invasions of exotic species.

I support the bill, and especially the establishment of the Exotic Birds Committee and the exotic bird registration scheme. I support the aim of the registration scheme to make it extremely difficult to trade in illegal birds. I would not accept the `extremely difficult.' It might make it more difficult but that does not remove the problem that exotic birds pose when they are legally imported. We will certainly support the main thrust of the bill, which is to protect endangered species—our own endangered species and those of other countries—from being imported into this country and to stop a trade which is absolutely despicable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see bipartisan support for the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995. It is very important. Everything to do with the environment usually crosses all political boundaries and I am very pleased by the support of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I was a bit concerned about the Gallus gallus chook. I did not know whether this was the one that strutted around and crowed, and did not lay eggs. All I have been used to in my career is black australorps and white leghorns. I have never come across a Gallus gallus but I will look that up!

This legislation strengthens some of the penalties. It creates new bodies to control imports and export of wildlife and, on the whole, it strengthens up a very good bit of legislation that we have had. One aspect of that strengthening is that the importing of endangered plants and animals from other countries, contrary to the foreign laws of those countries, will be punishable by five years gaol and a fine of up to $30,000. We are saying that if anyone abuses another country's laws we can actually prosecute them here, which is good. This should be done, as a method of tightening up and making certain that this trade in wildlife, both fauna and flora, is stopped.

This legislation will also make it possible to prosecute smugglers for cruelty. In a way, this reflects the outrage that has come from the general public when they see photographs of animals that have been kept in video cassette or tape boxes. Lizards have been smuggled in those sorts of things, birds have been drugged and put into coat pockets, and various snakes, lizards and things like that have been frozen and put into suitcases. People have then tried to transport them overseas and have been caught out.

One of the interesting variations on this is the fact that when, just recently, some smugglers were caught with bird eggs, one was actually caught egg in mouth. The idea of that, I suppose, was to keep the egg warm all the time and so when the egg got to the destination, wherever it was, it would have been warm all the way through. There have been some quite inventive ways of smuggling various wildlife and plants, and I will bring them up as I go through my speech.

The legislation will also give officers powers to seize hunting trophies from travellers entering Australia. I do not know whether elephants are an endangered species, but overseas I have actually seen elephants' legs being used as stands to keep umbrellas in, and that sort of thing. Trophies and things like that will be stopped from being brought into the country, and I think that is good. As the previous speaker said about the importation of birds, we should stop the importation of all birds and all animals, except for zoos. They should be given an exemption where the correct customs and quarantine regulations are in force but otherwise we should stop the importation of all animals to this country, because we do not know what sort of disease they will bring in and how quickly it can spread.

One has only to look at what has happened in recent days with the spread of the rabbit disease from an island in South Australia. According to the CSIRO it was going to be quite safe—it would not get across. They do not know how it has made its way across to the mainland. It could be by flies or mosquitoes. I know that it will please a lot of farmers and I too am pleased that the rabbit population will be wiped out, but we were not sure—and we still are not sure—of the effect it will have on other wildlife. Rabbits are similar to some of Australia's smaller creatures in size, so we do not really know the effect.

The other thing the disease will do is to wipe out a lot of foxes and feral cats. That is good because they will not be able to feed on the rabbits, but those foxes and feral cats will get a bit hungry in the meantime and proceed to get stuck into our Australian wildlife instead of eating rabbits. So there are spin-offs from that release into our wildlife which give a good example of how a virus, or some sort of insect, can be transmitted very quickly throughout the whole of this island nation.

In relation to laws that are put up by worldwide bodies in connection with smuggling, it is interesting to have a look at some of the world figures on smuggling of wildlife. Last year, there were at least five million birds, 25,000 primates and 10 million reptiles illegally taken from their homes in the wild. This is according to an organisation called TRAFFIC—Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce. That is, flora and fauna are being taken from their homes in the bush—they are stolen. Some are put into good homes as pets, but a lot of them get killed or get transferred to other countries where they can cause lots of problems.

It is not only animals that get stolen and illegally traded, but also plants—and they are very big business. It has been estimated, for example, that 9.3 million orchids, 7.5 million cacti and countless other twigs and flowering species are sold each year on the international market. Profits from this trade can be vast. Again, there are no true figures, but the estimates are that this sort of trafficking in flora and fauna and its sale is worth $27 billion per year. That is a huge amount of money.

In January 1994, the Bulletin gave some interesting statistics in relation to people in Australia who have been charged with smuggling wildlife. The article said that there had been a total of 119 offences since the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act came into effect in 1984. So there have not been many people since 1984, but I think that is just the tip of the iceberg. There is a lot of this going on and a lot of people getting away with it. But prosecutions have started, they have seized quite a lot of exports, and I think the bill will improve the lot of the Customs officers and, therefore, they will be able to bring more prosecutions. The Bulletin article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs officers have seized 207 Australian birds, 251 parrot eggs and 498 reptiles, as well as a large quantity of incoming exotic wildlife. About two to three times as many Australian animals have been seized by officials at Customs barriers overseas.

So we are missing out on a whole of this and it is being caught up overseas, but still there is a lot of it going on. Our parrots and other bird life are in demand overseas and our lizards and other reptiles are also in demand. Many of them are being sold and people are making vast profits out of the trade. Somehow or other, we have to stop it. The article goes on to say:
The worldwide illicit traffic in wildlife is estimated at $2.5 billion annually. The value of Australian wildlife seized in relation to prosecutions since 1984 is between $10 million and $15 million—

Therefore, those 207 Australian birds, 251 parrots and 498 reptiles add up to around $10 million to $15 million. You can see why it is a very lucrative trade for smugglers and crooks to be in, plus they are fairly hard to catch—or they have been in the past. The Bulletin article, as I said, was from January 1994, and it stated:
. . . the bird-breeding season in tropical Queensland is now in full swing but there are no wildlife rangers employed north of Cairns to enforce anti-trafficking laws.
This is a year ago and I do not know whether the situation is still the same. But there are a lot of islands between here and Papua New Guinea, and there is a big lot of air traffic going on.

PARA.TAB: I am sure the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) is aware of some of the things that happen up in North Queensland. I can recall being up there years ago and hearing all these strange aeroplane flights. Who knows where they were going! I am quite certain a lot of this goes on and a lot of birds are smuggled out through there. And there is no-one up there to watch it, no-one up there to actually catch anyone who is doing this poaching of these birds and animals.

People use some intriguing and interesting methods: they drug the birds and animals and they freeze the skinks. I do not know how people get away with it. An article in the Bulletin gives the following examples:

SPEECH.PARA: While cylinders in suitcases are the most common smuggling method, couriers employ other, sometimes quite bizarre, means. One woman had a monkey in a bra she was wearing; another had parrot eggs tucked under her breasts.
That was to keep them warm. The article continues:

A man had a shingleback lizard in his underpants; another had carp fish in plastic bags in his coat pockets. One smuggler had tarantula spiders hidden in a thermos flask. Parrot eggs have been found strapped to bodies and even inside the mouth of one courier.

As I said, a courier had birds' eggs in his mouth to keep them warm. Why would you do this? I suppose the profits are worth while. Some of the positions that these animals find themselves in would certainly be interesting! Giving another example of wildlife pets, the Bulletin says:
. . . in just four months recently, 8000 green tree-frogs were collected in the Mackay region in Central Queensland for sale to southern dealers.

That is, they are sold to dealers in New South Wales and Victoria. People want to keep green tree frogs: they are a nice looking animal, they make nice noises and they eat the insects. However, we should be stopping this transference of wildlife to people in the southern states. If people want to have green tree frogs, maybe they can start breeding them. There is a problem breeding all sorts of frogs, I believe, at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worldwide it is.

—Yes, it is worldwide and no-one seems to know what the problem is. Perhaps it is the pollution or the acid rain, or whatever. We are not quite certain. If people want to breed them, they can breed them in captivity and then they can sell them. There are many articles in relation to the way smugglers are actually working, mainly out of the Northern Territory and in North Queensland. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald says:

SPEECH.PARA: Smuggling flora and fauna in from north Queensland is a massive operation and may involve drug runners and organised crime.
This was said by someone giving evidence to the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and he is calling on them actually to investigate that illegal trade as well as drugs.

PARA.TAB: As I said, it is not just animals that are being sold off. It has been estimated that $30,000 worth of marine shells have been smuggled off the Great Barrier Reef in the last six years. The same article says that Customs officers agreed with estimates that over 700,000 foxtail palm seeds have been taken illegally from Cape Melville National Park this summer but that estimates that the seeds sell for $2 each are wrong and that their information was that they sell for up to $7 each in the US and $3 in Australia.

Huge money is being made by smugglers and people selling our wildlife overseas. What can we do about it? A suggestion has been put up and I think the suggestion and what we are doing now is quite good. We are making the laws harsher, we are enforcing them and we are bringing up better penalties. We are hopefully putting on more officers actually to enforce them and we are bringing more and more of these people to court. Hopefully, some of them will end up in gaol.

We had a good example of smuggling and theft of our wildlife. In Victoria, where I live, it was just recently discovered that $150 million worth of abalone is being stolen from Victorian waters and sold overseas each year. We are exporting more abalone than allowed by the permits that have been given for people to collect them. Where are all these exports coming from? They are coming from stolen abalone. This is another problem that is affecting our wildlife—and not only our flora and fauna but also our animals from the sea.

A very interesting hypothesis has been put forward by a Dr Hal Cogger, a senior and respected biologist. He says that wildlife smugglers are really the wrong people to be attacking, and that we should get to the other area. Dr Cogger is quite interesting, and I believe he has got a point here. He is the Deputy Director of the Australian Museum, and he notes that Australia's animal export laws are so strict that, technically, travellers need a permit to take their skin bacteria with them when they go overseas. When all those members of parliament are travelling overseas, they should have a look at what they have got breeding on their arms, et cetera, and they should have to get a permit!

Dr Cogger says that, despite fierce protection and eight active state and federal agencies with investigatory and enforcement roles, legal or illegal trading in native animals is really of minor significance to the survival of most of the species of native fauna. Making an educated guess based on known population densities of the various species of `herps', Dr Cogger reckons that Australia boasts a standing stock of about 192 billion individual reptiles and amphibians of all kinds and that, in any one year, about 39 billion of the total stock will die of natural causes; feral cats will kill another 240 million; land clearing, another 100 million; road-kills, five million; research collectors, 20,000; and public and private collectors, 8,000. The whole of the legal export trade may account for a few thousand animals and, while the impact could be significant for a few very rare species, it is trivial for most.

Dr Cogger is saying that the majority of the losses of all our animals are not through smuggling and theft but through normal processes—plus, as I said, clearing of land, road-kills, et cetera. Maybe that is what we have got to actually have a good look at. Maybe we have got to take into account not just the protection of our wildlife from smugglers but also the protection of our wildlife from us. Maybe we should be looking a lot more closely at the way we clear land, cut down our forests and allow feral cats and rabbits and foxes to run loose. If we put more effort into getting rid of those problems, we will save a lot more wild animals than we are saving through attacking those people who are making a profit out of them.

I also mention wildlife problems. Mention was made before of the death of the pilchards recently. No-one knows how this occurred. There has been a belief that it actually came through a disease that was brought into South Australia and that then slowly spread from there around the coast. Recently, I was with the Minister for Tourism, Mr Lee, down at Phillip Island, looking at the penguin parade there. I took him down to have a look because he had never seen the biggest tourist attraction in Victoria.

At the moment, the penguin numbers are quite good. About 700 are coming up of a night, and they feed on pilchards. Even though millions of pilchards have been killed, there are still millions there and the penguins are surviving quite well. But the problem is that, if there were any great loss in that pilchard area because of another outbreak of disease that kills off more pilchards, the penguin parade—which, as a tourist attraction, is something that is estimated to bring over $100 million into Victoria and $300 million into Australia every year—would be gone.

The other thing that could affect our wildlife down on Phillip Island in Westernport Bay, where we have these Ramsar agreements looking after migratory birds—more wildlife—is the fact that Shell and Mobil want to bring huge supertankers into the bay. Sooner or later, one of those supertankers is going to have an accident, and you only have to look at what happened recently in Tasmania to see the devastation that that would cause to our wildlife.

We should be looking at all facets of how our wildlife can be attacked, since we can lose our wildlife not just through smuggling but also through other human action. It is important that the government look closely at that aspect. With the figures that I gave before of the millions of animals being killed by various human encroachments on their land, we should look at the problem even more closely than we are now doing, and not just at what is happening in relation to the smuggling and theft of our wildlife.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking forward to making some remarks on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995, the aim of which is to improve the import and export control mechanisms for wildlife and which is consistent with the CITES agreement, which we ratified in this country in 1976, and the International Convention of Biological Diversity, which we ratified in 1993. It is worth nothing that the principal act was introduced by the coalition in 1982 and received the support of all parties then, as do these amendments.

PARA.TAB: I have listened with interest to some of the debate today and I do not object to any of the changes in these regulations and the increased controls, and increased penalties where appropriate. In fact, I happen to believe that the penalties for breaking these sorts of laws ought to be quite stultifying. I think what has happened a lot of the time is that penalties creep as time goes on, but the rewards creep higher for smuggling, so therefore the penalties really are taken in as part of the calculation in the business of smuggling. But these bills give us all an opportunity to perhaps put up some other ideas. Whilst we agree in general with these things, there are a couple of things that I would like to raise.

I notice that the states have been widely consulted and, whilst there is some disagreement in some areas, there is general agreement to the measures. I was interested the other day to be talking to several of the senior environment ministers in the states who were in agreement that, really, one of the things we have to do is to increase the commercialisation of Australian native wildlife. And I want to give what could perhaps be an example of this.

There is a dog fence, as everybody knows, which starts somewhere down at the Great Australian Bight. I have seen the end of it. As the fellow who showed it to me 30 years ago said, `If you cut that big wire that holds it there, she falls down all the way to Queensland.' But the fact of the matter is that it is some 1,600 miles long and, effectively, that was done to put the wild dog on the outside and the sheep on the inside. Inside that fence a great watering system sprang up over time to water the sheep, obviously, and the cattle, to some extent. And the by-product of all of that is that we have probably created the biggest single or double species—kangaroo and emu—wildlife park in the world. Nobody has ever, I suggest, immunised a species from its natural enemies and then made sure that it did not perish in the droughts which are so common in this country, and which certainly were before we produced these watering systems.

Just to extrapolate that a bit, other people, of course, have tried of recent times to breed animals by removing their natural predators—or their unnatural predators, in the case of the fox and the cat mentioned by the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and other people. It seems to me that whilst we have controls, penalties, regulations, punishments, and all sorts of people trying to make sure those regulations and controls are abided by, on the other hand we have the problem of our rarer species—and that is where, to some extent, I disagree with some of those who say we do not have a problem because of the numbers that are traded as opposed to the numbers that are still here—or the ones that we make rare for other people in other parts of the world that have the very high values. That makes the smuggling business worth the candle.

As has been said here today, that occurs in reptiles, birds and fish. And just to add to the extraordinary ways of smuggling that I have heard about in the last few days, of the list that the member for Dunkley produced, I understand that you can bring in fish spawn these days by taking the centre out of the biro, sticking it in your pocket to keep it at the right temperature, and daring anybody in Customs to start going through all your writing instruments. That came from somebody who ought to know, I understand.

I believe that our primary obligation in regard to Australia's native wildlife is not to the international conventions. We absolutely should not need any international conventions to enable us to look after our wildlife and our biodiversity. We have fallen down on that very badly, and I do not think anybody disagrees.

But I do not think that penalties and regulations are the only way to deal with the problem. As I said before, smuggling only works effectively when the rewards are high, and for some Australian species the rewards are very high. I am horrified when I see in the press the sorts of rewards that are available. Why would you write down—so that everybody can see it—that this species or that species is worth some vast sum of thousands of dollars and encourage every out of work 17-year-old to get into the business? It is quite an extraordinary thing to do, but then in some respects we do not expect the press to be always responsible.

We know that the rewards are high and that the smuggling of native fauna is going on apace; and that governments—this government, previous governments, state governments—have failed to stop it effectively. You would not need these amendments if we had stopped it. The blame is not to be sheeted home to anybody, and I agree that there has been much destruction of native wildlife by land clearing. I agree that there has been much destruction of native wildlife by introduced feral animals, and by the rabbit, which has destroyed vast areas of the environment of Australia over time and is still doing so.

Whilst you do not want viruses to escape from quarantine stations, I have been to Wardang Island, from where this latest calicivirus has escaped, and the quarantine arrangements that were put in place there were absolutely excellent. I cannot imagine how you could do it any better, unless you found an island further away, which is not all that easy and very expensive. In the 1930s, tests on myxomatosis took place on Wardang Island without the virus escaping from that island, although I think it escaped from the Mallee in the late 1940s and 1950s.

Sadly, we do need these viruses to destroy our major feral enemy. The rabbit has done more damage in this country than almost any other animal except man, and the quicker we can deal with it the better. That is an aside, but I will add to it, because the member for Dunkley raised an interesting point. If you are having a major rabbit program, you have to have a major fox and cat program at the same time. I do not think the foxes are all that difficult. It is a matter of money; it is a matter of strategies; it is a matter of planning.

The cat is much more difficult; it is much more cunning. In certain areas in Western Australia they can use 1080 poison, as the native wildlife is relatively immune to it. But we certainly cannot use that poison on this side of the continent because our wildlife is not immune to it. We will have a problem with the cat, but we have got a problem with the cat and the fox right now. It is important to remember that when these viruses and these controls are released for species X, greater effort must go into species Y, which otherwise might cause a problem at the same time.

We should be concentrating on how we can increase the populations of some of those rarer species which are likely to be at the top end of the value chain, or, alternatively, we make it less encouraging for those who want to get into the smuggling business? Perhaps we do it by exporting more of our native species. I have to be very careful, because I know that everybody can get terribly emotional about this. But I would like to think about the possibility of using the very best of science and the very best of commercial abilities in some of these areas of our rarer native species.

We have some very good examples. The first one is the campfire program in Zimbabwe—and we have just had the Zimbabwean delegation here in the last few days—which gives the locals some interest in the value of the local animals, in this case, elephants in particular. It is very sad that that damned drought is still going on in southern Africa after raging over the last four or five years with only small breaks.

The program is essentially trying to put some of the assets back in the hands of the local people and has in fact preserved the elephant population from the poachers in certain areas of Zimbabwe. I do not think we need to know how it is done, but those populations have been building up very substantially. I am told that the Zimbabwean government and other people in Africa are trying to extend that type of program to other species. I say, `More strength to their bow,' and we ought to be thinking about how we can do that.

I for one do not believe that zoos and government agencies are the only way that we should have breeding programs for native animals. John Walmsley in South Australia has shown, with rather mundane cat- and fox-proof fences, that native animals can survive very well without much more help. In other words, we need to have more intellectual input and to get rid of the old idea that governments can do all the protecting. I do not think that governments have the resources, quite frankly, and I agree with the member for Dunkley. One only has to think of the size of the coastline and the ease with which light aircraft can flop around from the mainland to the islands to the north; it is just an impossibility.

Although it will not apply to all species, we ought to be thinking of multiple ways of encouraging the commercial growing of the birds, the reptiles, the numbats, the bilbies and the what have you. There are some restrictions. States are rather jealous of those native populations—too jealous in my view—and something could and should be done about that with more consultation.

An organisation in North America called Ducks Unlimited started as a duck shooting organisation years ago, with people providing money to preserve wetlands, swamps and so forth. It quickly moved from being a duck shooting organisation to a wetlands preservation organisation, and contributions come in from duck shooters, photographers, tourist operators, little old ladies who live in New York, conservationists and all sorts of people—everybody one could think of who is interested in the wildfowl and wetlands bird populations in North America.

It quickly emerged that the resources from that private organisation were to be spent in Canada because Canada is the breeding place of the wildfowl population. Once a year, in four different fly aways, they all progress to the south, Mexico and other places, and then go back again in the northern summer.

I went to Canada this year to see how it is working. I know a fair bit about Ducks Unlimited but in the last four or five years it has expanded its operation enormously. It now has $US75 million of private money coming into the organisation every year; its budget for the next five years is $US500 million, so it is going to be $US100 million a year. They raise the money and it is donated by all sorts of means, as I said before.

The latest idea of the organisation is to lease swamplands from farmers and owners on a 10-year or 20-year lease. For the short lease, the only rule is that the farmer is not allowed to disturb the soil in the leased area until after 14 July each year when all the birds have bred and gone. In the 20-year lease period, there is re-sowing of the areas with the native species that were there before European occupation.

There is hardly a farmer in Canada who does not know about the program, nor a farm that is not involved in some part of the program. After all these years of moving earth around and doing all sorts of wetlands stuff like that, they have really hit on a way of involving everybody in the program, more or less in the way that the campfire program does. There is a little money in it, probably enough to appease the owner. All over Canada, in Manitoba and Saskatchewan at least, and in other places where all the so-called potholes are—we would call them swamps or wetlands—they are using a lease program with the owners to increase the wildfowl population.

That is an example of an enormously successful program which, even though it has been going for all this time—40 or 50 years—has in only the last few years hit upon a system whereby they can expand the wildfowl population. It would obviously not apply in Australia in that respect, because most of our wildfowl are grown in the big flood systems, in the Cooper, the Lachlan, the Murrumbidgee, the Darling and the rivers of Queensland and the Northern Territory and so forth. However, our big problem is that we do not have refuge areas when the things get tough, as they inevitably do in Australia.

It is possible that we could be using the sorts of ideas that are developing in Africa and other places to expand our ideas as to how we are going to deal with this problem, which really is the essence of why we have to have so many regulations and so many penalties. In the small time that I have left, I wish to say that it seems to me, therefore, that we need to be looking at how we can expand these populations and give somebody the incentive, quite legally and properly, to expand these populations. Probably you have to allow them, in the end, to be able to sell some of the things that they breed, or certainly to show them, in an ecotourism sense. But all of that needs to be thought about.

I notice that, in schedule 5, paragraph 13(1) of the bill was proposed to ensure that native species not recognised as being readily captive-bred are not exported. I want to raise the subject which I have just touched on. What does `readily captive-bred' mean? I do not think it means necessarily what we used to think it meant, and that was that they could be bred by agencies in zoos somewhere. It could mean that, with an expansion of our thought processes, we should be trying to expand the way in which we breed these native animals. Why should not native animals in this country, like the penguins and the rest, be an absolutely giant tourist attraction—but not in zoos or in particularly controlled areas?

Therefore, I am delighted to see that some people are now starting to think about removing predators from areas that are much bigger than just a few acres—some hundreds or thousands of acres at a time. That is the sort of idea that we have to expand; otherwise all that we—and the people that follow us in coming into these chambers—will be doing will be expanding the penalties and regulations, yet still failing because of the enormous size of this country.

I will just finish by raising the matter of one particular species. We have in South Australia a black cockatoo which is known as the Glossy black. It is a very delicate animal, feeding only on the seed nuts of casuarina trees. It does not look very mobile and it may be that the subspecies in my state has only 170 or 200 birds left.You would say that, on the surface of it, the game is all over and there is nothing to be done about it, because we have destroyed the habitat.

People are thinking that one of the reasons for the fall in numbers is that bees are occupying the places where the cockatoos normally live. Whatever the reason, it would be nice if somebody could be encouraged commercially to be able, with science and all the things that will be necessary, to reproduce a lot more Glossy blacks. If that were possible, why would anybody want to do it if they could not get some reward from it? Nobody could possibly put the money or the investment in, with a risk of failing—which is highly likely, I would suggest—unless there were some reward in it. We need to expand our thinking, not necessarily because we are going to sell all our wildlife overseas but so that people are encouraged to take some chances in increasing the native populations of wildlife in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise in support of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995. As has been said by a number of people making contributions to the debate, the purpose of this bill is to improve import and export regulatory controls, ensuring the long-term conservation of native wildlife consistent with Australia's international obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora—CITES—and the Convention on Biological Diversity.

PARA.TAB: The amendments in this bill arise, in the main, from the considerations of the so-called Ley report, the report of the review of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 entitled Australia's protection and conservation of wildlife. This amendment bill has been anxiously awaited. The director of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency said—perhaps quite rightly—in his introduction to the last annual report of the agency:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also disappointing that the Government continues to give low priority to amendments to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 which would make administration of the Act simpler and more effective.
Later, the report said about wildlife protection and the legislation:
A package of proposed amendments to the Act was agreed to by the Government in June 1993. To date, progress on the amendments has been limited due to the low priority accorded to them.

I suppose that is a bit of an indictment of us, but at last we have got around—some 2 1/2 years after the Ley report—to having this legislation before us, with amendments which, as has been stressed by the annual report of ANCA, are important.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say that Australia has not had a long history of measures that attempt to protect wildlife. As the Ley report mentioned, between 1898 and 1912 Victoria, followed by New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania, passed legislation to protect species. This parliament's interest is longstanding and the first regulations were promulgated back in 1911. They were subsequently reviewed in 1923, 1933 and 1935, and they continued in force until 1959, when a close examination of export policy was made.

I wish to bring it to the attention of the Main Committee that, in September 1976, a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, entitled Trafficking in fauna in Australia, was presented. The House of Representatives environment committee is a committee that I am a member of. It has a lengthy history in this parliament. It is probably the longest of the portfolio style committees that the House of Representatives has. At that stage the committee, whilst looking into the trafficking of fauna in Australia, concentrated in particular on investigations involving Australian bird life.

Whilst the committee did make mention of the problems of trafficking of other forms, such as mammals, reptiles and fish, mainly the investigation surrounded the large trade in Australian birds that existed at that time. So it is disappointing when we can pick up articles in newspapers like the Sydney Morning Herald of, say, April last year, alleging that the amount of smuggling of stolen native birds, reptiles and plants is worth an estimated $20 million, from just the Cape York peninsula. It is a problem that, whether we believe those sorts of estimates or not, continues to be of concern.

I was also interested that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) raised the issue of the article from the Sydney Morning Herald of November last year and quoted Dr Cogger, the Deputy Director of the Australian Museum. I think it is quite good and proper that people working in the scientific world should enter into debate about what the major ways are in which we can tackle problems like preservation of wildlife, preservation of endangered species and preservation of our biological diversity. But I think one should not get too overawed that pieces of legislation such as this are the be-all and end-all of tackling problems as outlined in this article. As the Ley report indicated, the control of the levels of exportation, the volume of international trade in certain wild animals and plants, is only one of the range of measures that we have to protect and conserve wildlife, not only at the federal level but, in the Australian federal system, at state and local levels.

We do have to look at things such as habitat protection; we do have to look at things such as establishment of national parks; we do have to look at scientific research into wildlife species and habitats; and we do have to set up systems such as registration of nature conservation areas through the Register of the National Estate. So it is not as if anybody is claiming that tackling the illegal trade in wildlife species is the be-all and end-all of it. I think it is valuable that people enter the debate and indicate that there are other things that impinge upon our ability to preserve our wildlife species. A comparison is made in the Sydney Morning Herald article of November 1994 which quotes Peter Mirtschen, who runs a venom supply company in South Australia. Referring to eight state and federal agencies between 1984 and 1993, he is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Between them, they successfully intercepted 950 individual animals or eggs of native fauna, mainly birds, being illegally exported by wildlife traffickers.
The article went on to say:
Mr Mirtschen points out that the entire haul was the equivalent of the number of native animals eaten by one feral cat in one year.

That is okay; I accept that. And I believe that through other programs, and other arms of what governments at all levels are attempting to do, we tackle those things. But we cannot ignore that there has been continuing interest throughout this country's history and that, as signatories to the conventions that have been mentioned, there are also the international obligations that we have to fulfil.

PARA.TAB: I take the point of the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) that perhaps these things are worthy to do, whether we have the international obligations or not. I think that is important. But, as has been stated by the honourable member for Dunkley, these problems are of a global dimension, so it is appropriate that the conventions such as the two that are involved with this bill codify the global action that needs to be taken. Then we can have some sort of confidence in the systems that are taken up by Australia through this legislation and also confidence that the obligations of other countries that are signatories and participants to those conventions are appropriate and proper. So we really have to realise that that is the importance of being able to have pieces of legislation such as this as part of our overall attempts to ensure that protection of wildlife is in place, and that protection of biological diversity is also in place.

Often I do not think we talk enough about the potentials that science gives us to be able to tackle some of these things. I did overhear the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) commenting that the speech by the honourable member for Barker was a good one and I would like to acknowledge that, too. In these debates there is a great deal of bipartisan support for the thrust of what is going on. There are often bipartisan minor criticisms, but I think they can also be taken on board.

The honourable member for Barker talked about black cockatoos. One of the things highlighted in the Bulletin article of January 1994 was that through the ability to use DNA profiling we are developing our ability to be able to assess whether or not animals—in this case, black cockatoos—have been bred in captivity. DNA profiling can compare the progeny to the parent stock and, therefore, there is some verification. The article indicated that:

SPEECH.PARA: Since DNA-profiling began, the number of cockatoo progeny declared by dealers has fallen sharply, indicating that many in the past were falsely recorded as captive-bred.
It is important that we continue to develop the scientific measures that will be of great assistance in our ability to monitor and, if required, enforce the measures outlined in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: No matter how good legislation is and no matter how severe the prescribed penalties are, unless we take appropriate action to enforce the measures within the legislation, we will fail. The other arm to pieces of legislation such as this is that we ensure that enforcement can be achieved.

The Ley report commented on enforcement and on the need to ensure that it was improved. Again, the consequent action that has to be taken after we legislate with bills such as this is that government—in this case, it requires cooperation between state and federal agencies—provides the resources to ensure that proper enforcement can be carried out.

In reviewing the 1976 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, while flicking through the recommendations at first I thought that it was quaint that the last of the recommendations was that the Commonwealth government should provide the Bureau of Customs with two suitable aircraft and sufficient patrol boats to enable it to meet its responsibilities in northern Australia, and necessary support facilities and staff. That was a very specific catalogue of the type of infrastructure that was required. I only highlight that to say that 20 years ago it was a concern of legislators that the agencies that were involved in policing similar regulations and legislation to this bill had not been given proper resources. To a certain extent, that continues to be a concern.

Much of the contribution by the previous speakers in the debate has considerable merit. There has been discussion about whether government agencies and publicly funded and managed zoos are the only things that we need to consider when we are putting in place appropriate programs to have captive breeding programs. I acknowledge that commercial concerns can play an important role but, at the end of the day, it is the responsibility of government to ensure that the framework that sets the standards and some of the goals that we wish to achieve is in place. It is then appropriate, through discussion between government agencies with the responsibility for monitoring, management and any commercial concerns, that those commercial concerns operate within management plans or protocols that fulfil the obligations that we have.

It will only happen through proper cooperation. I do not think that we should shy away from this notion that in some way, if we get government out of things, everything will flow and work out right. I think we have to acknowledge that in things such as environmental matters—highlights would be this legislation on the protection of our wildlife species and the protection of our biological diversity—it is important that we operate within specific frameworks. We probably do not stress enough the science and our baseline measurements.

Yet again, I note that newspapers are highlighting the fact that we have insufficient taxonomists to make sure that we know the real situation about the species that are out there. As I understand it, taxonomists classify different species. When we are out on inspections, we try to get a feel for what the real situation is and often agencies have to admit to us that they do not know the real situation. This lack of taxonomists is not a matter of resources but a matter of trying to encourage people to take on this discipline which plays a fairly important role in contributing to the gathering of our information base.

I am pleased that these amendments to the 1982 act are finally before us. I can understand the frustration of the agencies that are involved. I suppose that that in part reflects the low priority given to these things—not that that is something that we would wish to convey. These are important measures and, as I said, they should be seen in the context that they are important measures in an overall package that will try to achieve the aims that are set out in the conventions and, as has been illustrated by this debate, the aims shared by both sides of this parliament.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
